title: 104_hr4047
content: The Act titled "Medigap Amendments of 1996" includes amendments related to Medigap insurance. The "Medigap Amendments of 1996" Act includes changes to Medicare supplemental policies, ensuring coverage without preexisting condition limitations for continuously covered individuals. Insurers are prohibited from denying or conditioning policies based on health status or medical history. The "Medigap Amendments of 1996" Act prohibits insurers from denying coverage based on health status or medical history, ensuring individuals can enroll in policies without pre-existing condition limitations within 63 days of enrollment termination. The "Medigap Amendments of 1996" Act prohibits insurers from denying coverage based on health status or medical history, allowing enrollment in policies without pre-existing condition limitations within 63 days of termination. Enrollment may cease due to moving outside the service area, insurer bankruptcy, insolvency, or closure of business to new enrollment. Medicare supplemental policy coverage can be terminated due to insurer bankruptcy, closure of business, or change of residence to a different state. The individual may lose coverage under a Medicare supplemental policy if they move out of the issuer's licensed state, their employee welfare benefit plan providing supplemental health benefits terminates, or if their enrollment with an eligible organization is terminated within the first 12 months. An individual may lose coverage under a Medicare supplemental policy if they move out of the issuer's licensed state, their employee welfare benefit plan providing supplemental health benefits terminates, or if their enrollment with an eligible organization is terminated within the first 12 months. Medicare supplemental policies for individuals must have benefits that are comparable or lesser to the previous enrollment. The Medicare supplemental policy must have benefits that are comparable or lesser to the previous enrollment. State regulatory programs must determine benefit comparability. Organizations offering policies must address events leading to coverage loss. The insurer or plan administrator must notify individuals of their rights and obligations under the policy. Preexisting condition exclusions are limited during the initial open enrollment period. Nondiscrimination requirements are clarified for the 6-month initial enrollment period. The issuer of a medicare supplemental policy cannot deny coverage or discriminate in pricing based on health status, medical history, or disability. The 6-month initial enrollment period is extended to non-elderly individuals. The 6-month initial enrollment period for non-elderly Medicare beneficiaries is extended under part B. The amendment specifies the timeline for enrollment before the individual turns 65 or becomes eligible for benefits under part A. Effective Dates: The guaranteed issue policy will take effect on July 1, 1997. The limit on preexisting condition exclusions and nondiscrimination requirements will apply to policies issued on or after the same date. The extension of enrollment period for disabled individuals will also be effective on July 1, 1997. Before July 1, 1997, individuals enrolled for benefits under part B of title XVIII of the Social Security Act will begin a 6-month period for medicare supplemental policies. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will notify these individuals of their rights. Transition provisions will be made for States requiring regulatory changes to conform to the new policies. The State regulatory program must conform to changes in statutes or regulations related to section 1882 of the Social Security Act. The program will not be considered out of compliance solely for failing to make changes until a specified date. The National Association of Insurance Commissioners (NAIC) has 9 months to modify its NAIC Model Regulation regarding section 1882. The NAIC has 9 months to modify its NAIC Model Regulation regarding section 1882 of the Social Security Act. If the NAIC does not make the modifications within the specified period, the Secretary of Health and Human Services will make the necessary changes. The revised regulation will be considered the applicable NAIC model regulation. The regulation modifications must be made within 9 months by the NAIC or the Secretary will make the changes. The revised regulation will be considered the appropriate regulation for compliance. The specified date for a State is the earlier of when the State updates its statutes to align with the changes or 1 year after modifications are made by the NAIC or Secretary. Additional legislative action may be required for certain States identified by the Secretary. The specified date for a State to conform its regulatory program to changes made in the section is the first day of the first calendar quarter after the close of the first legislative session that begins on or after July 1, 1998. Each year of a 2-year legislative session is considered separate for this purpose. Each year of a 2-year legislative session is considered separate for the purpose of conforming regulatory programs to changes made in the section. The specified date for conformity is the first day of the first calendar quarter after the close of the legislative session. SEC. 3. INFORMATION FOR MEDICARE BENEFICIARIES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can provide grants to private consumer organizations and State agencies to offer understandable information to Medicare beneficiaries on enrolling in health plans and supplemental policies. This does not prevent grants for activities under the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990. The Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990 requires eligible organizations with Medicare contracts to conduct consumer satisfaction surveys and share the results with the Secretary and State Insurance Commissioner. The Secretary will then provide the survey results to organizations receiving grants. The Secretary will develop standards and criteria for comparing contracts and policies, including benefits, quality, costs, and consumer satisfaction surveys. Organizations with grants must provide complete, accurate, and uniform information to Medicare beneficiaries. An organization receiving a grant must share information with Medicare beneficiaries, consulting with various healthcare providers and insurers. They must meet specific terms and conditions to be eligible for the grant. The Secretary requires specific information in grant applications, with terms and conditions set for grant recipients. Organizations providing Medicare contracts or policies must pay a share of costs determined by the Secretary, not exceeding $35,000,000 annually. Amounts received are appropriated to the Secretary for grant purposes. In this section, funds are appropriated to the Secretary for grant purposes, with specific definitions provided for "Medicare managed care contract" and "Medicare supplemental policy."
